724169f-a.title: Manhattan: Washington Street - Christopher Street
724169f-a.text:
Washington Street, sast side, from Christopher Street to West 10th
(formerly Amos) Street, inclusive.
September 28, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
724169f-a.folder: Washington Street & Christopher Street, Manhattan, NY

718801f-a.title: Manhattan: Christopher Street - Washington Street
718801f-a.text:
163 Christopher Street, at the N. W. corner of Washington Street,
showing "T:cAvoy's Drug Storw" which was operated by a loc9l charscter
lovingly known as "Mother McAvoy." To sailors and truckmen of the
neighborhood she was more than a druggist. She was a friendly coun-
sellor, and a 'bank" and "post office" for sailors on their brief
stays ashore. From her old-fashioned desk in the store and through
her self-acquired knowledge of various foreign languages, and acting
as a Notary Public she helped many sailors turn to land lubbering.
Proximity to the Federal Building increased her field of operations.
She was born in Rome, N. Y. and was graduated from N. Y. C. P. in
1902. After clerking in several drug-stores she bought this little
store for 13500. At this time her olientele consisted of many New
Jersey people who commuted on the Christopher Street Ferry. She
died at the age of 64. For further details, see "The New York Times"
as of November 12, 1940.
NEG ~ E7(2:  1938.0
Alexander Alland
This photo is one of a series published in the volume "Portrait
of New York" by Felix Reisenberg and Alex. Alland, IRGV.
718801f-a.folder: Christopher Street & Washington Street, Manhattan, NY

724170f-b.title: Manhattan: Washington Street - Christopher Street
724170f-b.text:
Washington Street, east side, from Christopher Street to and
including Charles Street. Notice the Everard Storage Warehouse.
June 15, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, three months later, across the cleared N.W. corner
of Christopher Street. This view lacks the full N.E. corner,
at the right.
September 30, 1930.
P. I  .. Sperr.
